children.subject:
Can't give a specific recommendation because this question is so broad. However, there are a couple of things you need to consider before you pull the trigger on a monitor:

- What budget do you want to allocate for the monitor?

- How big is the monitor/what is the aspect ratio? 

- What resolution is the resolution? A larger monitor with lower resolution will look too blurry but a small monitor that's 4k will probably not be very great either.

- What panel technology does it use? IPS, TN, VA?

- What's the refresh rate, color accuracy, latency? 

- Ports? Some very high end monitors have a thunderbolt 3 port. Do you require that? 

- The stand the monitor comes in the box with is also something to consider if you don't plan on buying a third party stand/arm. Do you need to have a wide range of adjustments, tilt, pivot? 

This is definitely a lot to take in. Unless you have a very specific use case, I think asking on Facebook or friends/family if they have a spare monitor will suffice. Chances are it's a 21-24" 1080p monitor that will be more than enough for school.

history.content: <md>I've personally had a great experience with the [Dell P2219H Monitor](https://www.newegg.com/dell-p2219h-21-5-full-hd/p/0JC-0004-007H0), which I bought at the beginning of the pandemic. It comes in several different sizes depending on your preferences, isn't too expensive, and most of the sizes come on a stand that is tilt, pivot, and height adjustable which makes it really easy to configure for your particular workspace. I use it with a MacBook Pro via an HDMI adapter, but it also has other connection options. </md>

children.subject:
I think a monitor is very much worth it.

If you want to spend less than the below, just see what's on amazon in your budget; things to consider in that case are VA/IPS over TN + monitor size, resolution which will probably end up 1080p/ FHD, warranty/ reliability if you go for a no-name monitor.

My recommendations for the kind of monitor to get under 220$ and it being a good/decent price:

  • 1440p/ QHD (4K is also doable but more rare)
    • 1440p is enough for my 32" monitor in my opinion but 4K is a plus as things would be sharper
  • 27 inches (32 inches takes up too much space and is not that much better than 27 in my opinion)
  • VA or IPS, the two aren't that different unless you really care about colors; don't get TN it's just not worth it the colors are bad
  • (if I remember mac stuff correctly) you can get a monitor with a display port so that you won't need an adapter
    • but you will still need a mini-displayport/ thunderbolt (whatever your mac has) to full displayport cord; the nice thing about this is that unlike an adapter it doesn't have to do anything with the signal, only change the physical config of the wires
  • (won't fit into this price range unless you give up some of the above) thunderbolt 3 ports are generally too expensive to justify the costs
    • built in usb hub is a bit of a stretch but doable
  • (I have no knowledge on) how adjustable the stand is; mine has tilt only and that's enough for me; speculating, I'd say height adjustable is a solid plus but you can live without it, and I don't see the point in anything else.
  • (optional) VESA mount so that you can get a generic stand in the future

Some notes about adapters:

  • cheap ones may top out at 4k30fps, instead of the full 4K60fps; this is unacceptable in my opinion if you get a 4K monitor
    • if you get 1440p you don't have to worry about it if I remember right, as all modern HDMI's support 1440p 60fps

history.content: I feel like I waste a lot of time and energy switching between windows, and zoom just adds more to that issue, so I think having a second monitor would really help with my stress and productivity. I'm kind of lost on finding a good one, so does anyone have any recommendations? My laptop is a macbook pro.
history.subject: Second monitor recommendations?
